2.  Boiling water, which is extremely hot, will be poured over their heads. A hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) also explains this:

From Abi Hurairah, he recited this verse, he said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say, "Indeed, boiling hot water will be poured over their (the disbelievers') heads, then the hot water will penetrate their skulls down to their abdominal cavities, so it will destroy what is in the abdominal cavity, until the hot water reaches their heels and is in a liquid state, then (the body of that person) will return to its original state." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi)

3.  They will be whipped with whips made of iron, hitting their faces, heads, and entire bodies. From Abi Sa'id al-Khudriy, from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "If a whip of iron were placed on the earth, and then humans and jinn gathered, they would not be able to lift it from the earth." (Narrated by Ahmad)

4.  Every time they try to escape from hell, they are driven back and whipped with those whips, and it is said to them, "Taste this torment, as a reward for your denial and disobedience."

This is a description of the *ukhrawi* (hereafter) torment that Allah explains to mankind. With this explanation, humans can imagine how terrible and painful the torment that the disbelievers will receive on the Day of Judgment is, so that the description is a frightening message for them. This is one of the ways the Qur'an convinces humans and makes them aware of the denial and disobedience they have committed. What the true reality of the *ukhrawi* torment is, is included in the knowledge of the unseen; only Allah knows best, perhaps it is in accordance with what is depicted, which is physical torment, or perhaps it is physical and spiritual torment.
text.22:
This verse explains that the six groups of people mentioned above can be divided into only two groups: the disbelievers and the believers. Included in the group of disbelievers are the Jews, the Sabi'in, the Christians, the Magians, and those who associate partners with Allah. These five groups have different foundations of belief; one group does not acknowledge, and even denies, the fundamental beliefs of the other, so that disputes arise among them, sometimes escalating into hostility. The second group is the group of believers, namely those who are obedient to Allah. Debates and hostilities often occur between the first group and the second group, as depicted in the *sabab nuzul* (circumstances of revelation) of the verse above.

In this verse and the following verse, the forms of punishment and torment that will be received by the disbelievers, as well as the forms of blessings that will be received by the believers, will be described.

The torment that will be received by the disbelievers is explained by Allah as follows:

1.  The disbelievers will be thrown into a blazing fire of Hell, so that the fire covers their entire bodies, like clothing that wraps around and covers the entire body of the wearer.

In another verse, the condition of the disbelievers in Hell is also explained; they are enveloped by the fire of Hell until it covers their entire bodies. Allah says:

"They will have beds of fire and over them coverings [of fire]. And thus do We recompense the wrongdoers." (al-A'raf/7: 41)

Some scholars are of the opinion that the clothing that covers their entire bodies is made of extremely hot liquid asphalt, as Allah says:

"Their garments will be of liquid pitch, and fire will cover their faces." (Ibrahim/14: 50)

2.  Boiling water, which is extremely hot, will be poured over their heads. A hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) also explains this:

From Abi Hurairah, that he recited this verse, he said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say, "Indeed, boiling hot water will be poured over their (the disbelievers') heads, then the hot water will penetrate their skulls down to their abdominal cavities, so it will destroy what is in the abdominal cavity, until the hot water reaches their heels and is in a liquid state, then (the body of that person) will return to its original state." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi)

3.  They will be whipped with whips made of iron, until they hit their faces, heads, and entire bodies. From Abi Sa'id al-Khudriy, from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said, "If a whip of iron were placed on the earth, then humans and jinn gathered, they would not be able to lift it from the earth." (Narrated by Ahmad)

4.  Every time they try to escape from Hell, they are driven back and whipped with those whips, and it is said to them, "Taste this torment, as a reward for your denial and disobedience."

This is a description of the *ukhrawi* (Hereafter) torment that Allah explains to mankind. With that explanation, humans can imagine how terrible and painful the torment received by the disbelievers on the Day of Judgment is, so that the description is a frightening message for them. This is one of the ways the Qur'an convinces humans and makes them aware of the denial and disobedience they have committed. What the true reality of the *ukhrawi* torment is, is included in the knowledge of the unseen; only Allah is the All-Knowing. It may be in accordance with what is described, which is physical torment, or it may be physical and spiritual torment.
text.23:
In this verse, Allah explains the various blessings that will be received by those who believe and do righteous deeds, purifying themselves and their hearts, and always striving to draw closer to Allah. The various blessings that will be received are:

1. They will be admitted into gardens of perpetual residence beneath which rivers flow.

2. They will be adorned with beautiful ornaments, such as bracelets of gold, crowns adorned with beautiful gems and pearls.

3. For them will be provided beautiful garments of silk.

4. They are guided and taught, so they utter polite and pleasant words, perform deeds that please people, can interact well with other residents of Paradise, live in brotherhood, and love one another.

As with Allah's explanation of the punishment above, the depiction of blessings and pleasures described in this verse, as a reward that will be received by those who believe and do righteous deeds in the Hereafter, is similar to the blessings and pleasures that humans always dream of during their lives in the world. In general, humans while living in the world desire abundant wealth, to have a respected position and unlimited power, to have beautiful wives and luxurious household appliances.

Even though Allah has explained such things in His verses, the matter of Paradise and Hell is still a matter of the unseen for humans; only Allah knows the true reality. However, Muslims are obligated to believe that Paradise and Hell certainly exist. The description given by Allah is a portion of the promised pleasure. The true pleasure is beyond that description because there is nothing that can be used as a comparison for humans themselves. What is clear is that those who believe will experience unparalleled pleasure and blessings, never felt during their lives in the world, all pleasing to the heart, feelings, mind, sight, hearing, and so on.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah explains the various blessings that will be received by those who believe and do righteous deeds, purifying themselves and their hearts, and always striving to draw closer to Allah. The various blessings that will be received are:

1. They will be admitted to gardens of perpetual residence beneath which rivers flow.

2. They will be adorned with beautiful ornaments, such as bracelets of gold and crowns adorned with beautiful jewels and pearls.

3. For them will be provided beautiful garments of silk.

4. They are given guidance and lessons, so that they utter polite and pleasant words, perform deeds that please others, can associate well with other inhabitants of Paradise, live in brotherhood, and love one another.

As with Allah's explanation of the punishment above, the depiction of blessings and pleasures described in this verse, as a reward that will be received by those who believe and do righteous deeds in the Hereafter, is similar to the blessings and pleasures that humans always dream of during their lives in the world. In general, people during their lives in the world desire abundant wealth, honorable positions and unlimited power, beautiful wives, and luxurious household appliances.

Even though Allah has explained such things in His verses, the matter of Paradise and Hell is among the unseen for humans; only Allah knows the true reality. However, Muslims are obligated to believe that Paradise and Hell certainly exist. The description given by Allah is a portion of the promised pleasure. The true pleasure is greater than that description because there is nothing that can be used as a comparison for humans themselves. What is clear is that those who believe will experience unparalleled pleasure and blessings, never felt during their lives in the world, all pleasing to the heart, feelings, thoughts, sight, hearing, and so on.
text.25:
According to the narration of Ibn 'Abbas ra, this verse was actually revealed in connection with Abi Sufyan bin Harb and his companions. They were preventing the Messenger of Allah (saw) and his companions from entering the Masjidil Haram to perform the Umrah pilgrimage in the year of the "Treaty of Hudaibiyah." Therefore, the Messenger of Allah was reluctant to fight them because he was in a state of ihram. Then an agreement was reached, resulting in the Treaty of Hudaibiyah, which stipulated that the Messenger of Allah would not perform Umrah that year, but it would be postponed until the following year, and they would not prevent the Prophet and his companions from entering the Masjidil Haram to perform worship in the coming year.

This verse explains that all those who deny the Oneness and Power of Allah, deny the Messenger and reject the religion he brought, prevent people from entering Islam and upholding the word of Allah, prevent Muslims from entering the Masjidil Haram for worship, whether they are original residents of Mecca or newcomers from other countries, and prevent people from worshiping within it, Allah will inflict upon them a very painful punishment.

From the verse above, it is understood that the Masjidil Haram, located around the Ka'bah, is a place for Muslims to perform Hajj, Umrah, and other acts of worship, such as tawaf, salat, i'tikaf, dhikr, and so on, whether they are from Mecca itself or from outside Mecca. In other words, all Muslims have the right to worship in that place, wherever they come from. Allah threatens with severe punishment those who prevent and obstruct it. Therefore, some scholars question the status of the land around the Masjidil Haram, whether it can be owned by individuals or the government, or whether it is the right of all Muslims. For its regulation, it is now entrusted to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, because the Masjidil Haram is located in this country, as long as the country carries out the commands of Allah in serving those who want to worship there.

According to Imam Mujahid and Malik, the Masjidil Haram belongs to all Muslims, and no one or any country may own it. This opinion is also followed by Imam Abu Hanifah, their reason being the phrase "both residents and visitors" means that the Masjidil Haram is made for mankind, so that they may respect it and worship there, both for the people of Mecca and for those from outside Mecca.

Therefore, it cannot be said that the residents of Mecca have more right to the Masjidil Haram than the residents from outside Mecca.

Their other reasons are:

1. According to a narration, Umar, Ibn 'Abbas, and many companions held the opinion, "Visitors to the Masjidil Haram may occupy empty houses that they find unoccupied in Mecca, and the people of Mecca who own those empty houses should allow them to do so."

2. Hadith of Prophet Muhammad saw:

From Abdullah bin Umar, he said, "The Messenger of Allah said, "Mecca is a gift, its produce cannot be sold, and its houses cannot be rented out." (Narrated by ad-Daruquthni)

3. And another hadith of the Prophet saw: From 'Aisyah ra, she said, "O Messenger of Allah, may I build you a house in Mina or a house that can protect you from the heat of the sun?" He replied, "No, indeed that land is a gift for whoever gets it first." (Narrated by Abu Daud)

4. According to a narration, in the early days of Islam, the Masjidil Haram did not have entrance doors, so that at one time, many thieves came, then a man made doors, but Umar forbade him and said, "Are you closing the doors to those who make pilgrimage to the House of Allah?" The man replied, "I made the doors to protect the belongings of visitors from thieves." Therefore, Umar ra allowed it.

Imam Syafi'i is of the opinion that the land around the Masjidil Haram can be owned and traded, as long as it does not prevent Muslims from worshiping there.

From Umamah bin Zaid, he said, "O Messenger of Allah, may I visit your house in Mecca tomorrow?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Did the family of Aqil leave a house?" (Narrated by asy-Syaikhan)

This difference of opinion stems from the question: Was the conquest of Mecca (fathu Makkah) by Prophet Muhammad and his companions done by force or peacefully? If it was seized from the hands of the polytheists by force, then the land around the Masjidil Haram would be spoils of war for the Muslims, which must be divided according to religious provisions. But the Messenger of Allah did not divide it, so the land remains the property of the Muslims to this day. Sayidina 'Umar also did something similar in an area he had seized from the disbelievers. The second opinion states that the land of Mecca was seized by Prophet Muhammad saw peacefully, therefore it is not spoils of war, and remains the property of its owners at that time. Then it was inherited or sold by its former owners, so that it became the property of the buyer at this time.

Even though there are such differences of opinion, the scholars agree that the Masjidil Haram is a place of worship for all Muslims who come from all over the world. They may come whenever they wish, without anyone being allowed to disturb or prevent them. If personal or group interests conflict with the interests of Islam, then the interests of Islam must be prioritized and given precedence. Of course, Muslims who have settled and become residents of Mecca have the right and are allowed to earn a living from their efforts in serving and taking care of the pilgrims who come from all over the world. Even so, the effort to manage and serve the pilgrims should not be commercialized, but solely done to seek great reward.

The Masjidil Haram, as a holy place and the qibla of Muslims, has privileges and advantages, including:

a. In that place, even if a person only plans to commit immorality/treachery, Allah will punish him. Ibn Mas'ud, Ibn 'Umar, ad-dhahhak, and Ibn Zaid stated that if a person is in the Masjidil Haram, then he plans to kill someone who lives in Aden, Allah will punish him.

b. Worship performed in the Masjidil Haram has added value compared to worship in other places, even one salat in the Masjidil Haram is equal to one hundred thousand salat outside the Masjidil Haram. The Messenger of Allah said: From Jabir that the Messenger of Allah said, "Salat in my mosque (Masjid Nabawi) is a thousand times better than salat outside my mosque, except in the Masjidil Haram. And salat in the Masjidil Haram is a hundred thousand times better than salat outside the Masjidil Haram." (Narrated by Ahmad with a sahih sanad)
text.26:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to remind the polytheists of Mecca who were hindering people from entering Islam and the Masjid al-Haram about an event that had occurred in the past. This was when Allah showed Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), peace be upon him, the location of the Baitullah (House of Allah) that would be rebuilt, and when he proclaimed to all people in the world, upon Allah's command, that the Baitullah would be the center of worship for all mankind. By reminding them of these events, it was hoped that the polytheists of Mecca would no longer hinder people from entering Islam and the Masjid al-Haram, because Islam was the religion of their ancestor Ibrahim, and the Masjid al-Haram was built by their ancestor as well.

According to this verse, Ibrahim was the first person to build the Ka'bah. However, according to a narration, Ibrahim was only tasked with rebuilding the Ka'bah with his son Ismail (Ishmael), peace be upon him. The Ka'bah had been built before, then collapsed, and its remains were buried by sand. According to this narration, after Ismail, the son of Ibrahim and his wife Hajar (Hagar) whom he left in Mecca, grew up, Ibrahim came to Mecca from Palestine to carry out Allah's commands, namely to rebuild the Ka'bah with his son Ismail. Allah informed Ibrahim of the former location of the Ka'bah that had collapsed by blowing a strong wind to that place, making it clean. Then Ibrahim and his son Ismail built the Ka'bah in that place.

Then Allah commanded Ibrahim and his people to monotheize Allah; not to associate anything with Him, to cleanse the Ka'bah from all kinds of actions containing elements of shirk (polytheism), to purify it from all kinds of impurities and dirt, and to make the Ka'bah the center of worship for those who believe, such as performing tawaf (walking around the Ka'bah).

The words "salat, ruku' and sujud" (prayer, bowing, and prostration) are an indication that the Ka'bah was built for the Muslim ummah, because salat, ruku', and sujud are the hallmarks of Muslim worship performed facing the Ka'bah.

Allah has bestowed His great favor upon the Muslims, who have had their center of worship prepared long before their messenger was sent with the Islamic message. In other words, it can be said that the establishment of the Ka'bah carried out by Prophet Ibrahim upon Allah's command was a preparation for the delivery of the Islamic message. Because later on, the Ka'bah was made by Allah as the qibla (direction of prayer) for the Muslims and the place for them to perform Hajj and Umrah.
text.27:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) to call people to perform the Hajj pilgrimage to the Baitullah (House of Allah) and to convey to them that the Hajj pilgrimage is an obligatory act of worship for Muslims.

Most commentators (mufassirun) are of the opinion that Allah's command in this verse was addressed to Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) who had just finished building the Ka'bah. This opinion is in accordance with this verse, especially if we pay attention to its relationship with the previous verses. In the previous verses, Allah's command to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was mentioned to remind the polytheists of Mecca of the event when Allah commanded Ibrahim to build the Ka'bah, while these verses command those polytheists to remember the event when Allah commanded Ibrahim to call people to perform the Hajj pilgrimage.

This opinion is also in accordance with the narration of Ibn 'Abbas from Jubair, which explains that when Ibrahim (peace be upon him) finished building the Ka'bah, Allah commanded him, "Call people to perform the Hajj pilgrimage."

Ibrahim (peace be upon him) replied, "O Lord, will my voice reach them?" Allah said, "Call them, I will convey it." So Ibrahim ascended Mount Abi Qubais, then said in a loud voice, "O people, indeed Allah has truly commanded you all to visit this House, so that He may give you Paradise and protect you from the torment of Hellfire, therefore perform the Hajj pilgrimage." Then that voice was recognized by those who were in the loins of men and those who were already in the wombs of women, with the answer, "Labbaika, Allahumma labbaika" (Here I am at Your service, O Allah, here I am). Thus, the "talbiyah" came into effect in that way. Talbiyah is the prayer recited by a person who is performing the Hajj or Umrah pilgrimage, the prayer is, "Labbaika, Allahumma Labbaika."

Al-Hasan is of the opinion that Allah's command in this verse was addressed to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His reason is that all the words and conversations in the verses of the Al-Qur'an are addressed to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), including the command to perform the Hajj pilgrimage. This command was carried out by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) together with his companions by performing the Farewell Hajj (Hajj al-Wada'), as mentioned in the hadith:

From Abi Hurairah, he said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) gave a sermon before us, he said, "O people, Allah has obligated you to perform the Hajj pilgrimage, so perform the Hajj pilgrimage." (Narrated by Ahmad)

If we pay attention, then actually these two opinions are not contradictory. Because the command to perform the Hajj pilgrimage was addressed to Prophet Ibrahim and his people when he finished building the Ka'bah. Then after Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was sent, the command was also given to him, so that Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his people were also obligated to perform the Hajj pilgrimage, and it was even established as the fifth pillar of Islam.

In this verse there is the saying, "...they will come to you..." From this saying it is understood, as if God is saying to Ibrahim (peace be upon him) that if Ibrahim calls people to perform the Hajj pilgrimage, then people will surely answer his call, they will come from all corners of the world even though they have to travel a difficult and arduous journey. Whoever answers that call, whether at that time or later, then it means that he has come to answer Allah's call just as Ibrahim had answered it before. Ibrahim was once commanded by Allah to come to Mecca which was still deserted, Ibrahim fulfilled it even though his journey was difficult, through the scorching heat of the desert that stretched between Mecca and Syria. That command has been carried out well, even Ibrahim was willing to slaughter his own son Ismail, solely to carry out Allah's command, therefore Allah will provide a great reward for Ibrahim, and a reward like that will also be given by Allah to whoever visits the Baitullah, especially for those who deliberately come to Mecca to perform the Hajj pilgrimage. This saying is an honor for Ibrahim and shows how great the reward that Allah has prepared for those who perform the Hajj pilgrimage solely for Allah.

The scholars agree that coming to the Baitullah to perform the Hajj pilgrimage is permissible using any vehicles and methods that are permissible, such as walking, by ship or by airplane or by land vehicles and so on. But Imam Malik and Imam Asy-Syafi'i are of the opinion that going to perform the Hajj pilgrimage by using land vehicles is better and the reward is greater, because this method follows the actions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This method requires a lot of expenses, takes a difficult journey and adds to the symbols of the Hajj pilgrimage, especially when passing through countries that are traversed during the journey. Some scholars are of the opinion that walking is more superior to riding, because walking encounters more difficulties than riding. In this matter, riding or not is just a technical matter. In general, Islam does not want difficulties but ease. Islam also does not burden someone with something that he is not able to do.

Performing the Hajj pilgrimage, whether by vehicle or by walking, will surely get a great reward from Allah, if the worship is solely performed for Allah. What is assessed is a person's intention and sincerity and the ways of carrying it out. Even though the journey is difficult, but the intention to perform the Hajj pilgrimage is not for Allah, then he will not get anything from Allah, on the contrary he will be punished with a very painful punishment because of his intention.

If a person has arrived in Mecca and sees the Baitullah, it is recommended to raise his hands, as mentioned in the hadith:

Narrated by Ibn 'Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he said, "The two hands are raised in seven places, namely at the opening of prayer, when facing the Baitullah, when facing the hills of Safa and Marwah, when facing two places (Arafah and Muzdalifah) and when throwing two jamrah." (Narrated by Ahmad)

This hadith was practiced by Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him).
text.28:
This verse explains the purpose of the Hajj pilgrimage being prescribed, which is to obtain benefits. The forms of these benefits are not mentioned in this verse, only mentioned in general terms. The general mention of the benefits that will be obtained by those who perform the Hajj pilgrimage in this verse indicates the many kinds and types of benefits that will be obtained. These benefits are difficult to explain in detail, only those who have performed the Hajj pilgrimage and carried it out with sincere intention can explain and feel them.

These benefits are related to the spiritual and also to the physical, and some are directly felt by the individual who performs it, and some are felt by the community, both related to the world and related to the hereafter.

Many scholars have tried to uncover the forms of benefits that may be obtained by the pilgrims, after they have experienced and studied them, most of them stated that they were not able to uncover all the benefits. Among the benefits that have been revealed are:

1.  Training oneself by using all abilities to remember Allah with *khusyu'* on the appointed days by purifying obedience and submission only to Him. At the time when a person tries to control his desires by following Allah's commands and avoiding His prohibitions, no matter what hinders and obstructs him. The exercises carried out during the Hajj pilgrimage are expected to leave a mark in the heart and then can be repeated after returning from the holy land, so that it becomes a good habit in life.

2.  Creating a sense of peace and brotherhood among fellow Muslims. Since a prospective pilgrim wears the *ihram* clothing, white clothing that is not sewn, as a sign that he is performing the Hajj pilgrimage, from that moment on he has taken off worldly clothing, his favorite clothing, clothing of greatness, clothing of luxury and so on. All humans look the same in *ihram* clothing; there is no distinction between the rich and the poor, between the rulers and the common people, between the wise and the foolish, between masters and slaves, all are equally submissive and enslaving themselves to the Lord of the universe, all perform *tawaf* together, all run between the hills of Safa and Marwa, all jostle to throw stones at the *Jamrah*, all are equally submissive and *tafakkur* in the middle of the Arafah field. In such a situation, it will be felt that we are the same as other people. What distinguishes the degree between one person and another is only the level of piety and obedience to Allah. Therefore, there arises a desire to help each other, a sense of religious community, a sense of shared fate and burden, a sense of mutual respect among human beings.

3.  Trying to imagine life in the hereafter, at which time no one can provide help except Allah, the Almighty God. *Wukuf* in Arafah, the place where many people gather on the day of Arafah, is a picture of life in *Padang Mahsyar* later. All of that illustrates the moments when humans stand before the Court of Allah in the hereafter.

4.  Eliminating excessive self-esteem. When someone is in his country, he is usually bound by the customs that they usually do in their daily interactions. A slight change can cause misunderstandings, disputes and conflicts. When performing the Hajj pilgrimage, Muslims from all over the world meet, from different countries, each with different customs and lifestyles and procedures, so there is an intersection between customs and lifestyles. Such as how to speak, how to eat, how to dress, how to respect guests and so on. When performing the Hajj pilgrimage, there is contact and collision of bodies between pilgrims from one country, with pilgrims from another country, such as during *tawaf*, during *sa'i*, during *wukuf* in Arafah, during the throwing of *jumrah* and so on. When praying in the Masjidil Haram, the body of a person sitting is stepped over by another friend because he wants to get the front row, likewise the issue of language and gestures, all of which can easily cause misunderstandings and disputes. For someone who is performing the Hajj pilgrimage, all of that must be faced with patience, with an open heart, must be faced with the assumption that all the pilgrims do that not to hurt their friends and not to offend other people's feelings, but solely to achieve the maximum goal of the Hajj pilgrimage. They all want to obtain a *haji mabrur*, whether he is rich or poor and so on.

5.  Appreciating the life and struggle of Prophet Ibrahim along with his son Prophet Ismail and Prophet Muhammad along with his companions. When Ibrahim first came to Mecca with his wife Hajar and his young son Ismail, the city of Mecca was still a desert that had not been inhabited by a single human being. In such a situation, Ibrahim left his wife and son there, while he returned to Palestine. Hajar and her young son felt various sufferings, there was no place to complain and ask for help except only to God. As far as the eye could see, there were only rocky mountains, without plants that could be used as a place of refuge. One can feel the difficulty of Hajar running between Safa and Marwa looking for a drop of water for her child to drink. One can contemplate and take as an example about Ibrahim's obedience and submission to Allah. After that, he slaughtered his beloved son, Ismail, as a sacrifice, solely to fulfill and carry out Allah's command. Muslims during the Hajj pilgrimage can see the traces and places that are related to the struggle of Prophet Muhammad and his companions in upholding the religion of Allah. Starting from Mecca when he received obstacles, hindrances and even torture from the polytheists of Mecca, then he migrated to Medina, walking on foot, being chased by the infidels. Likewise, the efforts he made in Medina, fighting with the infidels, facing the cunning and slander of the hypocrites and Jews. All of that can be remembered and appreciated during the Hajj pilgrimage and is expected to increase faith and piety to Allah the Almighty, the Most Merciful and the Most Compassionate.

6.  Every Islamic Conference throughout the world. During the Hajj season, Muslims come from all over the world. Indirectly, there is a meeting between fellow Muslims, between ethnic groups and between nations with diverse patterns. Among them can chat and exchange experiences with others, so that a person's experience and thoughts can be taken and utilized by others, especially after each of them arrives in their country later. If a meeting like this is well organized, it will certainly be of great benefit, it will be able to solve the difficult problems faced by Muslims in their respective countries. All of that will also be beneficial for individuals, society and religion. It would be good if at that time there was a meeting between heads of state who performed the Hajj pilgrimage, a meeting of experts, scholars, community leaders, entrepreneurs and so on.

Although there are many benefits that will be obtained by those who perform the Hajj pilgrimage, only Allah can know for sure all the benefits. From the experiences of people who have performed the Hajj pilgrimage, it is found that their desire to perform the Hajj pilgrimage increases after they have completed the first Hajj pilgrimage. The more often a person performs the Hajj pilgrimage, the more that desire increases. The secret and benefits of the Hajj pilgrimage can also be understood from the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim to Allah, as mentioned in His word:

"So make the hearts of some people incline towards them." (Ibrahim/14: 37)

Another benefit of the Hajj pilgrimage is for people to mention the name of Allah on the appointed days and carry out the sacrifice by slaughtering sacrificial animals or *hadyu* (dam) for pilgrims who violate the obligations of the Hajj pilgrimage. As for its implementation, it is after throwing stones at the *jamrah 'aqabah* and is only carried out in the Haram land of Mecca. While the meat of *hadyu* (dam) is only intended for the poor in Mecca, unless there are no poor people in the city of Mecca, then the meat may be given to poor people in other cities/countries.

What is meant by the appointed days are the days of Eid al-Adha and the days of *tasyriq*, namely the 11th, 12th, and 13th of Zulhijjah. On these days, the slaughter of sacrificial animals is carried out. The time for slaughtering sacrificial animals is after the implementation of the Eid al-Adha prayer until sunset on the 13th of Zulhijjah. Rasulullah saw said:

"Whoever slaughters the sacrifice before the Eid al-Adha prayer, then he is only slaughtering for himself and whoever slaughters after the Eid al-Adha prayer (and after reading two Khutbah) then he has perfected his worship and has carried out the sunnah of the Muslims." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from al-Barra)

And Rasulullah saw said:

"All the days of *tasyriq* are the time for slaughtering the sacrifice." (Narrated by Ahmad from Jubair bin Muth'im)

After the sacrificial animal is slaughtered, then the meat may be eaten by the person who sacrifices and some of it is given as charity to the poor and needy. According to the majority of scholars, it is best for those who sacrifice to eat only a small portion of the sacrificial meat, while the majority is given as charity to the poor and needy. The person who sacrifices is allowed to give all of his sacrificial meat to the poor and needy.
text.29:
This verse explains that after those performing the Hajj pilgrimage have finished slaughtering their sacrificial animals, they should do three things:

1.  Remove any envy or impurities that are within themselves, namely by trimming the mustache, cutting the hair, cutting the nails, and so on. This is commanded because these actions are forbidden during the performance of the Hajj pilgrimage.

2.  Fulfill the vows that have been declared, because this is the best time, place, and circumstance to perfect the vow.

3.  Perform tawaf at the Ka'bah. What is meant by tawaf is circling the Ka'bah seven times. There are three types of tawaf:

    a. Tawaf qudum, which is the tawaf performed when first entering/arriving in Mecca.

    b. Tawaf Wada', which is the tawaf performed when leaving Mecca after completing the Hajj pilgrimage.

    c. Tawaf Ifadhah, which is the tawaf performed in order to fulfill one of the pillars of Hajj.

In this verse, Baitullah is called Baitul 'Atiq, which means "ancient house" because Baitullah is the first house of worship built by Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and his son Prophet Ismail (peace be upon him), and only then was Baitul Maqdis in Palestine built by Prophet Daud (peace be upon him) and Prophet Sulaiman (peace be upon them).
text.30:
This verse explains that all that was mentioned in the previous verses, such as shaving hair, cutting nails, fulfilling vows, and tawaf around the Ka'bah, are obligations that must be carried out by every person performing the Hajj. Whoever performs all that is commanded during their ihram, seeking to glorify and seek the pleasure of Allah, then that action is the best deed in the sight of Allah and He will reward it with multiplied rewards and a paradise full of delights.

According to Ibn 'Abbas, what is meant by "hurumatillah" are those things that are forbidden for people performing Hajj, such as committing wickedness, arguing, having intercourse with one's wife, hunting, and so on. Respecting "hurumatillah" means avoiding all these prohibitions. According to a narration from Zaid bin Aslam, what is meant by "hurumatillah" are al-Masy'aril Haram, Masjidil Haram, Baitul Haram (Ka'bah), the Sacred Months, and the Sacred Land. Respecting "hurumatillah" means doing good in those places, not committing sins, and this is the best deed in the sight of Allah.

In Hajj, there are two types of worship: worship related to the limbs, called "badaniyah" worship, such as tawaf, sa'i, throwing pebbles at the jumrah, and so on. The second is worship related to wealth, called "maliyah," such as slaughtering sacrificial animals and so on. In this verse, permissible foods are mentioned, and there is a command to avoid false speech. Although this command is directed to all Muslims, those who are performing Hajj are given the highest priority in carrying it out.

Allah explains that it is permissible for believers to eat and slaughter camels, cows, and so on, except for animals whose prohibition has been determined, as stated in Allah's words:

Forbidden to you are dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah, and [those animals] killed by strangling or by a violent blow or by a fall or by being gored to death or by being eaten by a wild animal - except what you [are able to] slaughter - and those which are sacrificed on stone altars... (al-Ma'idah/5: 3)

And Allah's words:

Say, "I do not find within that which was revealed to me [anything] forbidden to one who would eat it unless it be a dead animal or blood spilled out or the flesh of swine - for indeed, it is impure - or a debauchery committed to other than Allah..." (al-An'am/6: 145)

Allah never forbade eating animal meat as forbidden by the polytheists of Mecca; that was something they invented. They forbade Bahirah, Sa'ibah, Washilah, Ham, and so on, as Allah says:

Allah has not appointed [such innovations as] bahirah or sa'ibah or wasilah or ham. But those who disbelieve invent falsehood about Allah, and most of them do not reason. (al-Ma'idah/5: 103)

In this verse, two types of Allah's commands are mentioned:

1.  The command to avoid worshipping statues or idols, because that action causes impurity in the self and heart of the person who does it, and that action originates from the actions of Satan. Satan always tries to pollute the souls and selves of humans.

2.  The command to avoid false speech and giving false testimony.

In this verse, the mention of false testimony and idol worship together is because both actions are essentially of the same level; both are equally lying and denying the truth. From this verse, it can also be understood how great the sin of giving false testimony is, because it is mentioned after the prohibition of associating partners with Allah.

In a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), it is explained that false testimony is as serious as associating partners with Allah:

From the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he prayed Fajr, and after finishing the salam, he stood up and faced the people and said, "False testimony is as serious as associating partners with Allah, false testimony is as serious as associating partners with Allah, false testimony is as serious as associating partners with Allah." (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Daud, Ibn Majah, and ath-Thabarani)
text.31:
This verse affirms that humans must avoid idols and false speech by purifying their obedience to Allah, not associating anything with Him. Then Allah explains the magnitude of the sin resulting from committing shirk. Whoever associates partners with Allah has destroyed himself, because the person who commits shirk will obtain a great calamity in this world and the hereafter, with no hope left for obtaining salvation for himself.

This verse likens the person who commits shirk to someone who falls from a high sky, then his body is snatched by wild birds flying in the sky, the birds fight over his body, so that it is torn into small pieces, then his flesh is eaten by the birds, or his body is blown by the wind until it is thrown to a distant place, some fall into the sea, some fall into a deep ravine, and so on. Then there is nothing that can be expected from that person, except to receive eternal misery and torment.

Allah says:

"Indeed, those who disbelieve and avert [people] from the way of Allah have certainly gone far astray." (an-Nisa'/4: 167)

And Allah says:

"Say, "Shall we invoke instead of Allah that which neither benefits us nor harms us, and be turned back on our heels after Allah has guided us, like one whom the devils have enticed [to wander] upon the earth confused?"" (al-An'am/6: 71)
text.32:
Whoever honors the symbols of Allah, choosing sacrificial animals that are good, fat, and large, then indeed that is the action of a person who is truly pious towards Allah and an action that originates from the depths of the heart of a person who sincerely dedicates their obedience to Allah.

In a hadith, it is explained what kind of animals the companions used to slaughter.

From Abu Umamah bin Sahal, "We fattened sacrificial animals in Medina, and the Muslims also fattened them." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

And the hadith of Prophet Muhammad saw:

From al-Bara, he said that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "There are four types of defects that are not permissible in sacrificial animals: one that is blind in one eye, with obvious blindness; one that is sick, with obvious sickness; one that is lame, with obvious lameness; and one that is broken-legged, and one that cannot clean itself (severely emaciated)." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Ahmad)
text.33:
In this verse, it is emphasized that the sacrificial animals can be benefited from before being slaughtered, namely, they can be used as transportation on the journey to the holy land, their milk can be drunk, and so on. After being slaughtered, their fur can be utilized, their meat can be eaten, and given as charity to the poor and needy, as explained in the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw):

From Anas, that the Messenger of Allah (saw) saw a man leading a *badanah* (a camel fattened for sacrifice), so he said, "Ride it!" The man replied, "It is fattened for sacrifice!" Then the Prophet (saw) said, "Ride it! Woe to you!" the second or third time. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

The place for slaughtering sacrificial animals is around the Haram area or in the vicinity of the Ka'bah. Allah says:

O you who have believed, do not kill game while you are in the state of ihram [for Hajj or 'Umrah]. And whoever of you kills it intentionally - the penalty is an equivalent from livestock to what he killed, as judged by two just men among you as an offering [hadyu] brought to the Ka'bah, or an expiation [kaffarat] of feeding poor people or an equivalent in fasting, that he may taste the consequence of his deed. Allah has pardoned what is past; but whoever returns [to such violation] - then Allah will take retribution from him. And Allah is Exalted in Might, Owner of Retribution. (al-Ma'idah/5: 95)

The meaning of "brought to the Ka'bah" according to the verse above is to bring it to the Haram area to be slaughtered in that place.
text.34:
Allah has established laws for every human being, including the laws of sacrifice (kurban). A person who sacrifices means they have shed the blood of an animal to draw closer to Allah and seek His pleasure. Allah commands those who sacrifice to mention and glorify the name of Allah when slaughtering the sacrificial animal, and to be grateful for Allah's blessings bestowed upon them. Among Allah's blessings are livestock, such as camels, cows, goats, and so on, which are lawful sustenance and food for them.

From this verse, it can be understood that believers are forbidden from glorifying any name other than the name of Allah. After the arrival of Prophet Muhammad as the last prophet carrying the message for all of humanity, the true religion that must be followed by all of humanity is only Islam, which is based on the Qur'an and the Sunnah of Prophet Muhammad. Allah says:

"Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam. And those who were given the Scripture did not differ except after knowledge had come to them." (Ali 'Imran/3: 19)

Even more clearly, whoever seeks or adheres to a religion other than Islam will not be accepted by Allah and will be among the losers. Allah says:

"And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers." (Ali 'Imran/3: 85)

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) slaughtered sacrificial animals by mentioning the name of Allah and saying *takbir*, as mentioned in his hadith:

From Anas, he said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was brought two beautiful rams (on both rams there was a white color mixed with black) with good horns, then he mentioned the name of Allah and said *takbir* (when slaughtering them) and placed his foot on the side of the animal." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

At the end of the verse, it is emphasized that Allah, who has the right to be worshipped, is the One and Only God, and the belief in *tawhid* was also held by the people of the past. Therefore, be obedient and submissive only to Allah, follow all His commands, avoid all His prohibitions, and do all work solely for Him and to seek His pleasure.

Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to convey good news to those who are submissive, obedient, repentant, and humble themselves to Him, that for them is prepared a multiplied reward, in the form of Paradise in the Hereafter.

The statement "then your God is one God" gives a warning that sacrifice, honoring the symbols of Allah (*syi'ar-syi'ar*), and worshiping according to the guidance of the messengers sent to them, even though the worship and laws differ in each community, are included in the religion of Allah, including the straight path that must be taken by everyone who claims to be a servant of Allah, in obeying and seeking His pleasure. Differences in the ways of worship between the communities of the past and the communities that came later, including the community of Prophet Muhammad, should not be used as a reason that can cause division among believers. All of this is done with the aim of submitting oneself to the One and Only God.
text.35:
In this verse are mentioned the signs of those who are obedient and submissive to Allah, namely:

1. When the name of Allah is mentioned before them, their hearts tremble, because they feel His greatness and power. Hearing the name of Allah evokes feelings of hope and fear in their hearts. They hope for His pleasure, just as they hope for the forgiveness and reward that Allah has prepared for the pious. They deeply desire to be included in the group of the pious. They fear hearing the name of Allah, because they do not yet have sufficient preparation to face Him, such as the acts of worship they have performed, the good deeds and jihad they have undertaken; they feel that all of this is not enough, therefore they fear the punishment of Allah, which will be inflicted upon the disbelievers. They want to avoid that punishment.

2. They are patient in facing all trials from Allah. When they receive abundant sustenance and blessings from Allah, they remember that in their wealth there is a right for the poor and needy, therefore they pay zakat and give charity. When they become poor, they realize that it is a test of their faith, therefore poverty does not shake their faith in the slightest. They are certain that trials from Allah come in various forms and types, some in the form of pleasure and some in the form of hardship. Only those servants of Allah who are patient and steadfast will attain good fortune.

3. They always establish the obligatory prayers at the times that have been determined.

4. They spend from the sustenance that Allah has bestowed upon them. They perform the act of spending their wealth solely to seek the pleasure of Allah.
text.36:
In this verse, Allah explains that He created camels for humans to benefit from and made camels one of the symbols (syi'ar) of Allah by slaughtering them as sacrificial animals to draw closer to Allah. Then, He rewards those who sacrifice with multiplied rewards in the Hereafter.

According to Imam Abu Hanifah, based on the opinions of Atha' and Sa'id bin Musayyab from the Tabi'in, the term "Budna" mentioned in the verse refers to camels or cows. This opinion is also strengthened by the opinion of Ibn Umar, who stated that the meaning of "badanah" (singular of budna) is only known to be camels and cows.

One camel or cow can be sacrificed by seven people, based on the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) said, "We performed Hajj with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and we sacrificed one camel for seven people and one cow for seven people." (Narrated by Muslim)

If someone cannot find a camel/cow, they can replace it with seven goats, based on the hadith:

"From Ibn 'Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was approached by a man who said, "It has become obligatory upon me to slaughter a camel/cow, while I am capable of doing so, but I cannot find one to buy." So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ordered him to buy seven goats and then slaughter them." (Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Majah with a sahih [authentic] chain of narration)

Allah commands that His name be mentioned at the time of slaughtering. From this verse, it can be understood that it is haram (forbidden) to mention the name of anyone other than Allah at the time of slaughtering.

Once the sacrificial animal has been slaughtered, has fallen, and it is certain that it has truly died, then skin it, eat some of its meat, and give some of the rest to the poor and needy who ask and those who do not ask because they are ashamed to do so. Of course, giving all of it (the meat) is better and has a greater reward.

The people of pre-Islamic Arabia (jahiliyah) refused to eat the meat of the sacrifices they had slaughtered, so in this verse, Allah permits Muslims to eat the meat of their sacrifices.

Thus, Allah has made it easy for believers to control sacrificial animals, even though those animals are stronger than them. This can be taken as a lesson so that people are grateful to Allah for the blessings He has bestowed upon them.
text.37:
Allah affirms again the purpose of sacrifice (kurban), which is to draw closer to Allah and seek His pleasure. Closeness to Allah and His pleasure will not be obtained from the meat of the slaughtered animals, nor from the blood that has been shed, but all of that will be obtained if the sacrifice is done with sincere intention, done solely for Allah, and as gratitude for the countless blessings that He has bestowed upon His servants.

Mujahid said, "The Muslims once intended to imitate the actions of the polytheists of Mecca. When slaughtering sacrificial animals, they would scatter the meat around the Ka'bah, and smear the blood on the walls of the Ka'bah with the intention of seeking the pleasure of the gods they worshipped. With the revelation of this verse, the Muslims abandoned their intention."

Allah also affirms that He has made sacrificial animals easy for mankind, easy to obtain, easy to control, and easy to slaughter. With this ease, humans should be more grateful for the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon them and glorify Him, because of the guidance that He has given.

At the end of this verse, Allah commands the Messenger of Allah (saw) to convey good news to those who believe and do good deeds, and those who perform sacrifices with sincerity, that they will obtain His pleasure and bounty.

In the previous verse, Allah commanded to mention His name when slaughtering sacrificial animals, while in this verse, it is commanded to recite the *takbir* when slaughtering sacrificial animals.

Most *ahli tafsir* (Quranic commentators) combine these two recitations, namely mentioning the name of Allah and saying the *takbir*.

The utterance that is spoken is:

"In the name of Allah, Allah is the Greatest, from You and for You!"

The reason for this from the *mufasir* (commentator) is the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw).

From Jabir bin Abdillah, he said, "The Prophet (saw) slaughtered on the day of Eid al-Adha two rams that had sharp horns and were blackish-white in color. When he faced them towards the *qibla*, he said, (meaning) "Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward true religion," until the words, 'and I am the first of those who submit. O Lord! From You for You, from Muhammad and his ummah, in the name of Allah and Allah is the Greatest,' then he slaughtered them." (Narrated by Abu Daud)
text.38:
This verse indicates that believers always face trials and obstacles from the enemies of Allah and those who desire that the religion of Allah disappear from the face of the earth.

Nevertheless, Allah continues to defend the believers by strengthening their hearts, solidifying their steps to follow the straight path that Allah has laid out, and reinforcing their patience and steadfastness.

Allah's guarantee of His defense for the believers is affirmed in His word:

Allah has decreed, "I will surely prevail, I and My messengers." Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might. (al-Mujadalah/58: 21)

Therefore, it is obligatory upon those who have believed and have been helped by Allah to defend and uphold the religion of Allah, as a sign of gratitude for His help.

Allah defends the believers because they have kept their promise to uphold the religion of Allah. Therefore, Allah hates those who are treacherous and the *kafir* who have betrayed the covenant of Allah that He has established, as explained in the word of Allah:

And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes, we have testified." [This] - lest you should say on the day of Resurrection, "Indeed, we were of this unaware." (al-A'raf/7: 172)

They deny the commands of Allah and disregard His prohibitions, reject the verses of Allah, so that they will not be regarded by Allah in the Hereafter. Allah says:

Indeed, those who conceal what Allah has sent down of the Book and sell it for a small price - those consume not into their bellies except fire. And Allah will not speak to them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them. And they will have a painful punishment. (al-Baqarah/2: 174)
text.39:
This verse permits believers to fight against disbelievers if they have committed injustice on earth, oppressed believers, and opposed the religion of Allah.

Since Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) conveyed his message and carried out his da'wah to the Quraysh, the attitude of the polytheists of Mecca changed towards the Prophet and his companions. Initially, they considered Muhammad to be a trustworthy person, a just person who could resolve matters that occurred among them fairly. But after Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) conveyed his message, they then threatened, hurt, and took actions that were detrimental to the Prophet (peace be upon him), his companions, and so on. They even threw animal excrement at the Prophet and persecuted the companions, so that the suffering experienced by the Prophet and his companions was almost unbearable.

The companions once complained about this to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and asked him to allow them to retaliate against the actions of the disbelievers. The Messenger of Allah tried to calm and reassure the companions, because there was no command from Allah or verse revealed to resist and defend themselves. As the days passed, the suffering felt heavier and to avoid clashes with the disbelievers, the Muslims migrated several times, such as the migration to Abyssinia, to Ta'if, and finally the Messenger of Allah and his companions migrated together to Medina.

After the Muslims migrated to Medina, verses were revealed that commanded the Muslims to fight those who committed injustice against believers and tried to destroy the religion of Islam. This verse is the first verse revealed that relates to the command to fight. The second verse related to the command to fight is the permission for Muslims to fight disbelievers, but in a limited way, namely:

"And fight in the way of Allah those who fight you, but do not transgress. Indeed. Allah does not like transgressors." (al-Baqarah/2: 190)

The third verse commanding fighting is:

"Fight those who do not believe in Allah or in the Last Day and who do not consider unlawful what Allah and His Messenger have made unlawful and who do not adopt the religion of truth from those who were given the Scripture - [fight] until they give the jizyah willingly while they are humbled." (at-Taubah/9: 29)

dhahhak said, "The companions asked permission from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to fight the disbelievers who hurt them in Mecca, so verse 38 of this Surah was revealed. After migrating to Medina, verse 39 was revealed, which is the first *qital* verse revealed."

With this verse, the Muslims were permitted to fight. This verse was revealed after Allah forbade the believers from fighting for a long time and after the Messenger of Allah tried several times to reassure and restrain the enthusiasm of the believers in facing all kinds of actions by the disbelievers that hurt their hearts. Therefore, it can be concluded that permission to fight is given to Muslims if war is the only way out of difficulties that cannot be overcome. In other words: That warfare is permissible to defend oneself and to uphold and defend the word of Allah.

Actually, Allah is All-Powerful to defend and make victorious those who believe, without fighting and without experiencing misery and suffering. However, Allah wants to test the hearts of His believing servants, to what extent their steadfastness and patience are in facing Allah's trials, to what extent their obedience and compliance are in carrying out Allah's commands. How many people were initially considered good in faith, but after experiencing only a little trial, they returned to disbelief. With the command of *jihad*, there is an opportunity for believers to obtain Allah's greatest reward, namely the reward prepared for those who die as martyrs in defending the religion of Allah.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah explains the situation of those who are permitted to fight, because the polytheists of Mecca had committed inhumane acts against the Muslims. They were tortured, persecuted, hurt, and so on, not because of any wrongdoing or crime they had committed, but solely because they believed that there is no god worthy of worship except Allah, the Almighty. They no longer believed in the beliefs of their ancestors. They had surrendered themselves to Allah, the One God, and they had become Muslims.

The actions of the Meccan polytheists against the Muslims are explained in Allah's words:

"...they expelled the Messenger and you [believers] only because you believed in Allah, your Lord..." (al-Mumtahanah/60: 1)

The suffering and misery experienced by the Prophet and his companions because they believed in Allah, was also experienced by the messengers and their people who had been sent before. Allah says:

And those who disbelieved said to their messengers, "We will surely expel you from our land, or you will surely return to our religion." (Ibrahim/14: 13)

Those who are permitted to fight had previously been expelled by the polytheists from their homelands, had been tortured and hurt without just cause. If the actions of the polytheists were allowed to continue, their tyranny would surely increase, and the longer it went on, the more power-mad they would become. They would destroy monasteries, churches, houses of worship, and mosques in which the name of Allah is mentioned and glorified. Therefore, Allah legislated in His religion that every believer who is prevented from worshipping his Lord should defend his religion, fight in the way of Allah, but defend the truth, and reject falsehood and injustice.

In essence, the war that takes place is a war between truth and falsehood, a war between those who have received guidance from Allah and those who deny that guidance. Such a war is a war whose purpose is to build human life, namely a prosperous worldly life that is pleasing to Allah and a happy and eternal life in the hereafter ( *ukhrawi* ).

This verse also indicates that every group of Muslims should have a mosque built by the members of that group. In the mosque, the names of Allah are glorified, congregational prayers are performed at all times, the lives and livelihoods of Muslims are discussed, and the mosque is used as a place to gather and deliberate.

In this verse, Allah strengthens the command to fight in the verse above, by giving commands and promises. What Allah commands is that Muslims help and defend the religion of Allah, strive and carry out the commands of Allah. What is promised is that whoever defends the religion of Allah is entitled to Allah's help, in the form of victory and reward in the hereafter.

Allah says:

And it is ever incumbent upon Us to help the believers. (ar-Rum/30: 47)

Allah's promise will surely be fulfilled, because He is All-Powerful and All-Mighty. Allah says:

O you who have believed, if you support Allah, He will support you and plant firmly your feet. (Muhammad/47: 7)

At the beginning of the verse above, Allah promises victory to those who believe. Then, at the end of the verse, Allah reaffirms that victory is certain for those who believe. At the beginning, the Muslims did not yet believe in the truth of the promise, so it needed to be strengthened by the second statement. The intention is to calm and reassure the heart, and strengthen resolve at a time when the Muslims are being tested by Allah.

At the end of the verse, Allah fulfills the promise that He has made to those who believe. He is All-Powerful to do all things, and no one can prevent the occurrence of any of His will.

Allah says:

And Our word has already preceded for Our servants, the messengers, [that] indeed, they will be those given victory. And [that] Our soldiers will be those who overcome. (ash-shaffat/37: 171-173)
text.41:
Then Allah explains the characteristics of those who were driven out of their homes without just cause. They are the companions along with the Prophet Muhammad (saw), to whom Allah had promised victory. If they had obtained victory, they would not be like the polytheists and those who are power-hungry, but they would continue to implement:

1.  Prayer at every appointed time in accordance with what Allah has commanded. They were truly convinced that prayer is the pillar of religion, a direct connecting cord between Allah and His servant, purifying the soul and body, preventing people from immoral and evil deeds, and a true manifestation of piety (taqwa).

2.  They pay zakat. They believe that in the wealth of the rich there is a right for the poor and needy. Therefore, in paying zakat, it is not because they pity the poor and needy, but solely to surrender the right of the poor and needy that is in their wealth. If they are appointed as rulers, they strive to ensure that the rights of the poor and needy truly reach their hands.

3.  The command to enjoin good (ma'ruf) and forbid evil (munkar). They encourage people to do good deeds, leading people through the straight path that Allah has laid out. They greatly hate those who habitually violate Allah's prohibitions.

Allah's promise is indeed true. They obtained the promised victory. Allah established them as managers of worldly affairs and leaders of religious communities well. In a short time, the Muslims were able to control areas outside the Arabian Peninsula.

Their actions are in accordance with Allah's word:

"You are the best nation produced [as an example] for mankind. You enjoin what is right (ma'ruf) and forbid what is wrong (munkar) and believe in Allah. If only the People of the Scripture had believed, it would have been better for them. Among them are believers, but most of them are defiantly disobedient [to Allah]." (Ali 'Imran/3: 110)
text.42:
These verses are a balm for the heart of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the hearts of his companions who were distressed and troubled by the arbitrary actions of the polytheists of Mecca against them. It is as if Allah is saying to Prophet Muhammad, "O Muhammad, if the polytheists of Mecca deny you, disregard you, even oppose your call, commit corruption on earth, hurt and torture your companions in various ways, do not be sad, do not despair, and strengthen your heart in facing them, because the people of the past also denied the messengers who were sent to them, but I gave them help, so that victory was on their side."

Allah says:

"Until, when the messengers despaired and were certain that they had been denied, there came to them Our victory, and whoever We willed was saved. And Our punishment cannot be averted from the criminals." (Yusuf/12: 110)

Thus, Noah (peace be upon him) was denied by his people, they threatened and disobeyed him, including his own son. Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) was denied by his people, namely the 'Ad people, Prophet Saleh by his people, namely the Thamud people, as were Abraham, Lot, and Shu'aib. All of them were denied by their people, hurt and tortured, but they remained steadfast and patient. The harsher the torture and opposition from their people, the stronger their faith became. Finally, victory was on their side.

Moses was denied by Pharaoh and his people, they did not believe in all the miracles that Moses showed, even though they could not defeat Moses (peace be upon him) or bring about miracles like the miracles of Prophet Moses. Because they remained disbelieving, the sunnah of Allah applied to them, namely that Allah helps those who believe and destroys all the disbelievers who disobey Him, at the time He determines.

Pay attention to the history of the people of the past who opposed the messengers who were sent to them, eventually all were struck by terrible disasters, so that the arrogance, joy, and pleasure that were in them turned instantly into unparalleled sadness and misery. Then, after experiencing that terrible disaster, in the Hereafter they will be afflicted with a painful torment. Changing luxury and pleasure into misery and suffering, a victory turning into a defeat in a very short time is very easy for Allah, the All-Powerful and All-Wise, to do.

Allah says:

"Indeed, the assault of your Lord is severe." (al-Buruj/85: 12)

And Allah says:

"And such is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the cities while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe." (Hud/11: 102)
text.43:
These verses are a balm for the heart of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the hearts of his companions who were distressed and troubled by the arbitrary actions of the polytheists of Mecca against them. It is as if Allah is saying to Prophet Muhammad, "O Muhammad, if the polytheists of Mecca deny you, disregard you, even oppose your call, cause corruption on earth, hurt and torture your companions in various ways, do not be sad, do not despair, and strengthen your heart in facing them, because the people of the past also denied the messengers who were sent to them, but I gave them help, so that victory was on their side."

Allah says:

"Until, when the messengers despaired and thought that they had been denied, there came to them Our victory, and whoever We willed was saved. And Our punishment cannot be averted from the criminals." (Yusuf/12: 110)

Thus, Noah (peace be upon him) was denied by his people, they threatened and disobeyed him, including his own son. Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) was denied by his people, namely the 'Ad people, Prophet Saleh by his people, namely the Thamud people, as were Abraham, Lot, and Shu'aib. All of them were denied by their people, hurt and tortured, but they remained steadfast and patient. The harsher the torture and opposition from their people, the stronger their faith became. Finally, victory was on their side.

Moses was denied by Pharaoh and his people, they did not believe in all the miracles that Moses showed, even though they could not defeat Moses (peace be upon him) or bring miracles like the miracles of Prophet Moses. Because they remained disbelieving, Allah's sunnah applied to them, namely Allah helping those who believe and destroying all the disbelievers who disobey Him, at the time He determined.

Then, after experiencing the terrible disaster, in the Hereafter they will be afflicted with a painful torment. "Indeed, the vengeance of your Lord is severe." (al-Buruj/85: 12)

"And such is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the cities while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe." (Hud/11: 102)
