"And such is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the cities while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe." (Hud/11: 102)
text.45: This verse explains that Allah has destroyed many lands because their inhabitants associated partners with Allah, caused corruption on earth, and acted unjustly. Many lands were utterly destroyed, their roofs collapsed, and then were struck by the ruins of their walls. Many wells were no longer used by their owners because the owners had died or perished along with the destruction of those lands, due to their disobedience to Allah. Likewise, many palaces and towering mansions were empty, uninhabited, because their arrogant and arbitrary inhabitants had perished. All of this was a recompense for their disobedience and violence and serves as a valuable lesson for people who come later, who wish to attain happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.46:
The polytheists of Mecca who denied the verses of Allah and rejected the call of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) actually often traveled between Mecca and Syria, as well as to countries around the Arabian Peninsula. They carried merchandise on their journeys, seeing the remnants of the ruins of the lands of nations that Allah had destroyed in the past, such as the remnants of the land of the people of 'Ad and the people of Thamud, the ruins of the land of the people of Lot and the people of Shu'aib, and so on. The polytheists of Mecca had also heard the tragic stories of those disobedient people. Did they not think and reflect on all these events and incidents, that their actions of denying the call of Muhammad and torturing his companions were the same as the actions of the nations of the past towards the messengers who were sent to them? If the actions were the same, then surely the consequences would also be the same, namely that they would receive calamity and severe punishment from Allah. Allah is All-Powerful to do whatever He wills, and no one can prevent Him.

Seeing the attitude of the polytheists of Mecca like that, it turns out that their eyes were not blind, because they could see the remnants of the ruins of the land of the disobedient people, but in reality, it was their hearts that were blind, closed to accepting the truth. What closed their hearts was the influence of their customs and beliefs from their ancestors. Therefore, they felt envious of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his companions, so that they could no longer think and reflect on all kinds of sorrowful events that had occurred and befallen the previous nations.
text.47:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists of Mecca who denied Allah's verses, rejected the call of the Prophet Muhammad, and did not believe in the Day of Judgment, asked the Prophet Muhammad to inflict upon them the punishment that had been inflicted upon previous peoples. They made this request because they were sure that the punishment would not come.

Their request was answered by Allah that the punishment they asked for would surely come, because it is Sunnatullah (Allah's way). Allah will never break His promise. However, the punishment will be inflicted upon them at a time determined by Allah, not according to the time they desire. Only Allah knows when the punishment will come, just as the punishment came to previous peoples, which came suddenly, without anyone knowing from where and when the punishment would come.

As Allah says:

"Do the people of the towns feel secure against Our punishment coming to them at night while they are asleep? Or do the people of the towns feel secure against Our punishment coming to them in the morning while they are at play?" (al-A'raf/7: 97-98)

If the polytheists of Mecca feel that a long time has passed, but the promised punishment has not yet come, so they think that the punishment will not come again, then let them remember that a thousand years according to their feelings is the same as a day in the sight of Allah. Therefore, let them remember that Allah will surely fulfill His promise after a long time has passed according to their feelings. Allah delaying the coming of the punishment does not mean that He has broken the promise He made.

Scientifically, this verse implies the concept of time relativity. A concept introduced by Albert Einstein through the Theory of Relativity. Previously, for almost 200 years, the world of physics was dominated by Newtonian physics which stated that time is constant; one hour is the same everywhere under any conditions.

The following example will illustrate the concept of constant time. Suppose, Hamzah and Wildan have synchronized the time on their respective watches. Then, using an airplane that has a high speed, approaching the speed of light, Hamzah departs leaving Wildan. After one hour (according to his watch) Hamzah returns from his journey and meets Wildan. Then, Newton would say that Wildan would also feel that he had been waiting for Hamzah for one hour. Wildan's watch will show the same time as Hamzah's watch.

Einstein would disagree with this. According to him, time is relative, depending on the speed of movement of a person or something. If Hamzah, who is moving at a speed close to the speed of light, feels that he has left Wildan for one hour (according to the watch on his hand), then Wildan's watch will show that Hamzah has been gone for 10 hours. If Hamzah leaves at 8 am, then when he returns, Hamzah's watch will show 9 am, while Wildan's watch will show 6 pm. Likewise, if Hamzah and Wildan are both 20 years old, then Hamzah travels leaving Wildan at a speed close to the speed of light for 5 years (according to Hamzah's time), then when they meet, Hamzah will be 25 years old, while Wildan will be 70 years old. Thus, time is relative.

The Qur'an has hinted at this since 14 centuries ago. Allah manages affairs from the heavens to the earth and back to the heavens at a very high speed so that all of this only lasts one day which is the same as 1000 years according to our calculation of time. This relativity of time is also found in as-Sajdah/32:5; al-Ma'arij/70: 4.

In this verse, one day is equivalent to 50,000 years. This could happen, depending on the speed of movement of the angels.
text.48: Allah does everything according to His will and wisdom. In this regard, humans must also remember one of Allah's attributes, which is that He does not immediately punish His sinful servants before giving them the opportunity to repent by believing and doing good deeds. If the opportunity to repent is not used by His servants, then they will be afflicted with the promised punishment. Therefore, how many lands whose inhabitants acted unjustly, after some time, they did not repent, but instead became more unjust, then Allah inflicted punishment upon them suddenly from directions they did not know. Let mankind remember that everything in the universe belongs to Allah, including what is within it, and everything will return to Allah. When they return to Him, all their deeds will be weighed; good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise full of blessings, while bad deeds and evil actions will be rewarded with Hell whose fire blazes fiercely.
text.49:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to convey to those who requested the hastening of the punishment that inflicting the punishment was not the task of the messengers. The task of the messengers is only to deliver warnings and threats from Allah to mankind, including themselves. The task of the messengers is also to convey that the actions that the polytheists have committed have brought them to the threshold of the threatened punishment. The messengers have no authority to judge the deeds of servants, because it is Allah alone who grants guidance and direction. Allah says:

"It is not [required] of you, [O Muhammad], to guide them, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2: 272)

If Allah willed to inflict the promised punishment, He would certainly have done so, and doing so is easy for Him. Therefore, do not ever ask the messenger to hasten or postpone the punishment, because all of that is within Allah's authority.

With the delivery of the threat and warning, people whose hearts are open to receiving Allah's guidance have the opportunity to avoid the threatened punishment of Allah, namely by doing all that Allah has commanded, stopping all that is forbidden, and striving to erase all their sins by performing righteous deeds. If they persist in disbelief, then Allah will surely carry out His threat by inflicting a painful punishment upon them whenever He wills.
text.50:
In this verse, Allah explains the form of warning and threat by mentioning the good reward for those who believe, and the threat of punishment for those who disbelieve. Those who believe in the true sense, and the manifestation of their faith is evident in their actions of performing righteous deeds, then Allah will forgive all their sins, reward their good deeds with manifold rewards and a noble provision. In the Hereafter, they will be admitted into Paradise, a place where they will obtain everything they desire, as Allah says:

"Enter Paradise, you and your spouses, in happiness." Circulated among them will be plates and cups of gold. And therein is whatever the souls desire and [what] delights the eyes, and you will abide therein eternally. (az-Zukhruf/43: 70-71)

Furthermore, it is explained in a hadith that in Paradise there is pleasure and happiness that has never been felt by humans during their life in the world, as Allah says in a hadith qudsi:

"In Paradise there is what no eye has ever seen, what no ear has ever heard, and what has never occurred to the heart of man." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)
text.51:
As for those who persistently strive to oppose the messengers, wanting to destroy Islam and the Muslims, they will be cast into the fire of Hell, and that is the worst place that Allah has prepared for them. Allah says:

"Those who disbelieve and avert [people] from the way of Allah - We will increase for them punishment upon punishment for what corruption they were causing." (an-Nahl/16: 88)
text.52:
In this verse, Allah warns the believers about the efforts made by Satan; both Satan in the form of jinn and Satan in the form of humans, to mislead people from the path of Allah.

Among Satan's efforts is that when the Messenger discusses the verses of Allah, or explains and conveys the Sharia that he brought to his companions, then those Satans arise and strive to insert into the hearts of the listeners a false interpretation, so that they believe that the verses or Sharia conveyed by the Messenger did not originate from Allah, but are merely the words of the Messenger, fabricated to convince people of his prophethood and apostleship. There are also among those Satans who insert a false interpretation of the verses, so that without being realized by the listeners, they have deviated with the interpretation itself from the true meaning of the verse.

Satan's efforts are not only directed at the Qur'an and the hadiths of the Prophet, but have also been directed at the religion and holy books that were revealed to the messengers. Some of Satan's efforts have been successful. If one studies diligently the history of the religion brought by the messengers and the history of the holy books revealed by Allah to them, it will be seen that Satan has inserted many things into those religions that can mislead people from the path of Allah. What is inserted is not only something light and not a principle, but many things have been successfully inserted that can change the basis and core of the religion. Allah says:

"They distort words from their [proper] usages and have forgotten a portion of that of which they were reminded. And you will still observe deceit among them, except for a few of them." (al-Ma'idah/5: 13)

The religions that Allah revealed to the previous messengers that have been greatly interfered with by the actions of Satan include the religions of Prophet Ibrahim, Prophet Musa, Prophet Daud, and Prophet Isa (peace be upon them).

In the history of the Muslims after the death of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his closest companions, the efforts to damage and change the Islamic religion are clearly visible, although the efforts to change, add to, or subtract from the verses of the Qur'an were not successful, because the Qur'an is preserved by Allah. However, they almost succeeded in inserting false hadiths into the collection of the Prophet's hadiths. In addition, they almost succeeded in interpreting the verses of the Qur'an with interpretations or *ta'wil* that are far from the meaning of the Qur'an that is intended.

In addition to their efforts to change the holy verses of the Qur'an, the hadiths of the Prophet, and Islamic Sharia, they also strive to damage the lives and livelihoods of people. For example, if a person aspires to have something good in himself, then Satan creates in that person's self and mind the opinion or belief that the desired aspiration is difficult to achieve, so that fear and a feeling of inability to achieve that good aspiration arise in that person's self and will.

Regarding the Qur'an, there have been many efforts to imitate it, insert false interpretations and *ta'wil* into it, insert superstitions, and so on, but all these efforts have failed. This is in accordance with Allah's guarantee regarding the preservation of the Qur'an. Allah says:

"Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an, and indeed, We will be its guardian." (al-Hijr/15: 9)

If we pay attention to the history of the Qur'an, there are many ways that have been taken to maintain the authenticity of the Qur'an, including:

1.  During the lifetime of the Messenger, every verse of the Qur'an that was revealed, he ordered to be written down and memorized.

2.  Not long after the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died, the entire Qur'an had been collected and written on sheets that were then bound and stored by Abu Bakr, after Abu Bakr's death it was stored by Umar, then by Hafsah binti Umar. During the time of Usman, the Qur'an written on those sheets was compiled into a book. The Qur'an was named "Mushaf". There were five *mushafs* written during the time of Usman. From those five *mushafs*, the Muslims throughout the Islamic world at that time copied the Qur'an.

3.  Encouraging and increasing the enthusiasm of knowledgeable people to deepen their knowledge. With the existing knowledge, they can maintain the purity of the Qur'an from all kinds of *shubhat* and false interpretations.

4.  Since the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) until now, there have always been people who have memorized the entire Qur'an, so it is difficult to make insertions into it. Even the slightest writing error in the verses of the Qur'an has been able to cause a strong reaction from the Muslim community.

In every period of Islamic history, there have always been figures of scholars who are able to defend and maintain Islamic teachings from attacks that come from outside Islam in various forms.

At a time when many efforts to falsify hadiths arose at the beginning of the second century of the Hijra, Caliph Umar bin Abdul Aziz appeared. He tried to collect and compile the hadiths of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that were still in the memory of the *tabi'in*, and some had been written by the companions. He ordered officials in the regions and scholars to collect the hadiths of the Prophet in their respective regions. Among the scholars who wrote it was Imam az-Zuhri. So Imam az-Zuhri collected the hadiths of the Prophet. Even though at that time there had not yet been research and separation of which hadiths were false and which really came from the Prophet, this effort was the foundation and basis for the efforts that would be made by the Imams of hadith who came later after the generation of az-Zuhri, such as Imam al-Bukhari, Muslim, an-Nasa'i, Abu Daud and others. These Imams conducted research on the hadiths that had been collected during the time of Caliph Umar bin Abdul Aziz.

Likewise, Imam al-Asy'ari succeeded in maintaining the purity of Islamic teachings from the influence of Greek philosophy, which was widely studied by Islamic scholars at that time. Then al-Gazali also succeeded in maintaining Islamic teachings from the strong teachings or influence of Neoplatonism. Ibnu Taimiyah has cleansed Islamic teachings from various misleading *khurafat*.

Allah is All-Knowing of everything, including all forms of Satan's efforts to damage and change Islamic teachings, everything that is in the hearts of people, everything that is visible and everything that is hidden. With His knowledge, He thwarts the deception of Satan who wants to damage His religion, and then inflicts a fitting punishment on them.
text.53:
Allah explains the various efforts of devils and their followers to deceive mankind by adding false understandings to the verses of the Al-Qur'an and in the Islamic religion. Their actions become a trial for mankind, especially for those who believe, those who deny, those whose hearts are astray, and the hypocrites. The temptation of the devil adds to their error and causes disease in their hearts, so that their disbelief and hypocrisy increase.

Meanwhile, those who are strong in faith will not be deceived by the devil; every temptation of the devil that comes to them will strengthen their faith. Conversely, those whose hearts are astray and have disease within them will stray far from the right path, making it difficult for them to return to the right path. They can no longer expect the pleasure of Allah and will not escape the punishment of Allah.
text.54:
Allah does that so that those who possess knowledge may know and contemplate all kinds of laws that Allah has established, the fundamental principles of *sunnatullah*, all kinds of *subhat* and misinterpretations of verses made by Satan and his followers. With that knowledge and experience, it is hoped that their faith will increase, believing that the Qur'an truly originates from Allah, just as they believe that Allah guarantees the authenticity of the Qur'an from human interference and from incorrect interpretations.

Therefore, those who believe, who have been able to distinguish between right and wrong, between faith and disbelief, should submit and surrender themselves to Allah. Reading the verses of the Qur'an earnestly, carrying out all that He has commanded, stopping all that He has forbidden, whether related to worship, *muamalat*, character, law, and the proper way of interacting in community life.

Then it is emphasized that Allah will indeed give guidance and *taufik* to His servants who believe and follow all the messengers. The guidance and *taufik* that Allah gives to His servants are done in various ways. There are direct ways and there are also indirect ways; sometimes humans themselves realize that they have received that guidance.

In the life history of the Prophet Muhammad saw, there are many instances where Allah gave direct guidance to him. Among Allah's guidance to him was Allah's rebuke to the Prophet when the Prophet did something that was considered inappropriate for a messenger to do, for example, His rebuke to the Prophet for belittling a companion who asked him a question, while the Prophet was busy with the Quraysh leaders. Among the examples are as follows:

Imam Ibn Jarir narrates that Ibn Ummi Maktum, a blind and poor companion of the Prophet. One day he came to the Prophet and said, "O Messenger of Allah, recite and teach me what Allah has taught you." He repeated those words three times. At the time Ibn Ummi Maktum asked, the Messenger saw was receiving the Quraysh leaders, namely Walid bin Mugirah and supposedly enemies of the Muslim community, while Ibn Ummi Maktum did not see and did not know that the Messenger of Allah was busy receiving his guests. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah saw felt displeased with Ibn Ummi Maktum's request; he frowned and turned away from him. The attitude of the Messenger of Allah towards Ibn Ummi Maktum was rebuked by Allah with His words:

He frowned and turned away because there came to him the blind man (Abdullah bin Ummi Maktum). But what could tell you that perhaps he might purify himself or be reminded and the remembrance might profit him? As for him who thinks himself self-sufficient, to him you give attention. And no blame is on you if he does not become pure (believes). But as for him who came to you striving earnestly and fearing (Allah), of him you are neglectful. No! Indeed, it is a reminder. ('Abasa/80: 1-11)

With Allah's rebuke, the Messenger of Allah became aware of his mistake; from that time on, he increasingly respected his companions, including respecting Ibn Ummi Maktum himself. This rebuke from Allah is what distinguishes the Prophet's position from ordinary humans.
text.55:
This verse explains the attitude of the disbelievers towards the Qur'an. They do not believe in the Qur'an, even though evidence of its truth has come to them, proving that the Qur'an is the word of Allah and not Muhammad's creation.

Despite Allah's rebuke to the Prophet, as mentioned above, the disbelievers remain doubtful and unwilling to believe in Allah until the Day of Judgment or until punishment comes to them.
text.56:
Allah clarifies that when the Day of Judgment arrives, everything will be in Allah's hands. He is the One who has power at that time and the power to settle all matters by giving appropriate recompense to humans, according to the deeds they have done during their lives in the world.

Those who believe in the Qur'an, practice all that is contained within it, believe in Muhammad as the Messenger of Allah, practice his hadith, carry out Allah's commands and cease from His prohibitions, will be given the reward of Paradise filled with delights. They will obtain what they desire, experiencing happiness and pleasure that they have never felt during their lives in the world.
text.57: The disbelievers who deny the verses of Allah, insert false interpretations and create doubts into His verses, claiming that the Qur'an is Muhammad's creation, will be afflicted with a very severe punishment, the severity and weight of which cannot be compared to any torment or calamity that they have ever experienced during their lives in the world.
text.58:
This verse explains that all those who emigrate in the path of Allah, leaving their homelands, leaving their families and possessions, solely to seek the pleasure of Allah, with the aim of upholding the religion of Islam alongside Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and then are killed in battle or die normally in that state, then Allah will open up a noble provision for them in the Hereafter.

Some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that in reality, those who are killed or die normally in a state of emigration to defend and uphold the religion of Allah will both be given a noble provision in the sight of Allah. That is what is meant by this verse, and it is also mentioned in the word of Allah:

"And whoever emigrates for the cause of Allah will find on earth many dwelling places and abundance. And whoever leaves his home emigrating for Allah and His Messenger and then death overtakes him - his reward has already become incumbent upon Allah. And Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful." (an-Nisa'/4: 100)

And in a hadith of the Prophet (peace be upon him):

From Salman al-Farisi, he said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say, "Whoever dies in a state of duty (ready to fight in the path of Allah), he is given provision, and is safe from all that tempts him. And recite if you wish (this verse)." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim)

From this verse, it can also be established as a ruling that if there is a good deed, in accordance with what the religion commands and is done by several people, and in the execution of that work some Muslims die because of that work, and some die normally while carrying out that work, then those who die normally are given the same reward by Allah.

In this verse, there is the phrase "noble provision." Allah does not explain what is meant by that noble provision, and when that provision is given. This will be explained in the following verse (verse 59).

Then Allah explains that He is the best of providers. The meaning is that Allah gives provision to His servants solely because of His mercy for them, so He gives it infinitely to whomever He wills, without expecting any reward from His servants.
text.59:
Allah will admit all those who are killed in His path and those who die in a state of emigration into Paradise full of delights in the Hereafter, as a reward for what they have done.

This is what is meant by sustenance in verse 58, and when that sustenance is given by Him. Allah explains that He knows all the deeds that have been done by those who emigrated, knowing all the good deeds they have done, both small and large, both visible and hidden. Just as Allah also knows the deeds of the wrongdoers. Even so, Allah does not immediately inflict punishment upon the wrongdoers, because He is also Most Forbearing. Allah always gives those who sin the opportunity to repent and return to doing good deeds that are pleasing to Allah.
text.60:
Thus, Allah will grant good sustenance and a Paradise full of delights to those who die in a state of *hijrah* and *jihad* in the path of Allah, in fighting their enemies.

Then Allah affirms His guarantee of help to those who perform *hijrah* and *jihad*, namely, whoever among the believers retaliates against the torment of the disbelievers, because they have been fought, then their enemies force them to perform *hijrah*, leaving their homelands, surely Allah will help them and will repay that deed in return.

In addition, Allah is Most Forgiving and Most Merciful to His servants. Therefore, believers should not fight their enemies who have surrendered, and they should protect those who seek protection from them. If the disbelievers allow the Muslims to practice their religion, without disturbing or harming them, Allah forbids fighting those disbelievers. Allah commands to forgive their mistakes, just as Allah has forgiven the mistakes of the believers. Allah says:

"And those who, when tyranny strikes them, defend themselves. And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it, but whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is [due] from Allah. Indeed, He does not like wrongdoers." (ash-Shura/42: 39-40)
text.61:
Providing help and guaranteeing victory for those who believe is a definite promise from Allah. Because He is the All-Powerful over all things. Among the signs of His power is that in one summer He inserts the night into the day, so the day becomes long, and in one winter He inserts the day into the night, so the night becomes long. In the equatorial region, the difference between night and day is not so noticeable. But in subtropical and polar regions, this difference is very visible. In winter, the night appears very long, while in summer, the day is longer than the night.

The verse above is one of many verses in the Qur'an that repeatedly express the matter of the creation of day and night. (QS 10;67, 16:12, 17;12, 21:33, etc.). And that happens solely because of His power, which is reflected in the initial sound of the verse.

According to scientists, night and day are natural phenomena that occur because of the Earth's position moving around the sun in a fixed "almost circular" orbit. Because of this, the Earth is spared from experiencing deadly extreme temperatures. The round Earth, while orbiting the sun, continues to rotate on its axis. Night occurs on the part of the Earth that is not illuminated by sunlight, and day occurs when other parts of the Earth are exposed to sunlight. Night is dark and day is bright.

Regarding the Earth's rotation on its axis, data shows that its speed is 1,670 km per hour. Compare this to the speed of a bullet when fired from a modern weapon, which is 1,800 km per hour. How fast the Earth rotates!

Meanwhile, the Earth's orbital speed around the sun is 60 times the speed of a bullet, which is about 108,000 km per hour. At that speed, an airplane could circle the Earth in just 22 minutes.

The Earth's rotation on its axis occurs once a day, which, according to experts, is the right speed to produce moderate and comfortable temperatures for life on the Earth's surface. And even more amazing is the size of the Earth's axis of rotation, which has made it possible for 4 seasons to occur in the northern and southern hemispheres of the equator and only 2 seasons in areas located right on the Earth's equator.

The precision of the rotation that results in the regularity of the occurrence of day and night on Earth is affirmed by this verse, "...It is not allowable for the sun to overtake the moon, nor can the night outstrip the day. Each floats along in [its own] orbit." (Yasin/36:40)

With the periodic and regular alternation of day and night, a decree of Allah to be a calculation of time for human life on Earth. One cycle of day and night, Allah SWT determines to be 24 hours. This is what we know as the calculation of days. One day is 24 hours. Meanwhile, one rotation of the moon (as an Earth satellite) orbiting the Earth takes 29 or 30 days. Or it is called one month. While the length of time it takes for the Earth to orbit the sun one full rotation is 360 days, and it is known as one year. All of this is the basis for compiling time calculations or calendars.

Inserting the night into the day, and inserting the day into the night, according to human standards, is more difficult to do than giving victory. Therefore, giving victory to the oppressed is very easy for Allah to do. Allah hears all the prayers that His servants ask of Him and sees all the actions that His servants do.
text.62:
Such attributes, namely perfect power, vast and complete knowledge encompassing all kinds of knowledge, belong to Allah, because He is *wajibul-wujud* (necessary existence), whose existence is certain, possessing all kinds of perfect attributes, without the slightest deficiency. He is the possessor of the true religion, conveyed by the prophets and messengers He sent, the last of whom was Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). He is the One and Only God, without any partners. Therefore, worshipping Him is obligatory, the most truthful thing to do, and likewise His help and His promise are the truth. Everything worshipped besides Allah is a false object of worship, and that worship is baseless. He has the power to create whatever He wills. If He wants to create something, it is enough for Him to say, "Be!" and it comes into existence.

Indeed, Allah is Most High, everything is beneath Him, and He is above all things. There is nothing like Him in strength, loftiness, greatness, and knowledge.
text.63:
In this verse, Allah mentions signs of His greatness, which are also blessings bestowed upon humanity. Does humanity not see and observe that Allah drives the clouds, and then from those clouds, rain descends upon the earth? This rainwater fertilizes the earth, causing various kinds of plants and vegetation to emerge, beautiful in form, as if the earth adorns itself with the growth of plants and vegetation of various colors. Among the things that grow, some can be eaten by humans, thus preserving their survival. Others can be used as materials for clothing, beauty products, and various other human needs.

Indeed, Allah is Vast in Knowledge, because His knowledge encompasses all of His creation. Nothing escapes His knowledge, from the smallest to the largest, from the simplest to the most difficult and complex, which is sometimes unknown to humans. Therefore, Allah regulates and maintains the survival and existence of His creation. Thus, laws and provisions are established to govern His creation.

Regarding Allah's knowledge of His creation, it is explained in His word:

"Not absent from your Lord (even) an atom's weight within the earth or within the heaven. And not [is there] smaller than that or greater but that it is in a clear register." (Yunus/10: 61)
text.64: To Allah belongs all that is in the heavens and all that is on the earth; nothing is associated with Him in that ownership. Therefore, He alone determines what He does with His creation, and nothing can hinder His will. He is in no need of anything, only His creation is in need of Him. He is the Most Praiseworthy because of the infinite goodness and blessings that He has bestowed upon His creation.
text.65:
Among the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon His servants is that He has subjected and facilitated for mankind to utilize everything contained within the earth and everything on its surface, so that it can be used for the benefit of human life and existence. Mankind is given the knowledge and ability to plant and cultivate crops, to mine various kinds of minerals. Then Allah shows the ways to utilize all of it. Allah says:

And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth - all from Him. (al-Jashiyah/45: 13)

Mankind has been granted much knowledge by Allah. Sometimes some of them become arrogant and conceited with the knowledge they possess. Let mankind remember that the knowledge given is only a little compared to Allah's knowledge that is unknown to mankind. Human knowledge is meaningless compared to Allah's knowledge, as Allah says:

And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about the soul. Say, "The soul is of the affair of my Lord. And mankind have not been given of knowledge except a little." (al-Isra'/17: 85)

Thus, Allah has subjected and facilitated the mastery of ships and the sea to mankind. Ships are facilitated to sail the oceans, carrying humans and their needs to all corners of the world. With these ships, humans also seek sustenance in the seas in the form of fish, pearls, minerals, and the treasures of the sea in the form of countless fish.

Allah created the universe, which consists of outer space and its countless planets. All float and orbit through paths determined by Allah. Each planet has its own gravity, so it does not fall apart, unless Allah wills it. Allah says:

When the sky breaks apart and when the stars fall, scattering. (al-Infithar/82: 1-2)

All of this was not created by Allah by chance, but with a specific purpose, with neat and meticulous laws and provisions. With these laws and provisions, humans can benefit from them, they can fly in the universe, ascend to other planets, they can predict weather conditions. They can travel from one country to another in a short time, and many other benefits they can derive by using Allah's provisions and laws. All of this shows the Lord's love for mankind.
text.66:
Among the greatest blessings of Allah bestowed upon mankind is creating humans alive from inanimate objects, giving them spirit, soul, intellect, and feelings, so that humans can live and enjoy life, and cultivate the earth for their pleasure. With that soul, intellect, and feelings, humans can also carry out Allah's commands and abstain from His prohibitions, so that in the Hereafter they will be showered with the greatest blessing of all, unparalleled, namely Paradise which He has promised.

Despite the abundance of Allah's blessings bestowed upon mankind, few people are grateful to Him; in fact, many among them deny Him, some even disobey and associate partners with Him in worship. Allah says:

"How can you deny Allah when you were lifeless and He gave you life; then He will cause you to die, then He will give you life again, and then to Him you will be returned." (al-Baqarah/2: 28)

And Allah says:

"Say, 'Allah causes you to live, then causes you to die; then He will assemble you for the Day of Resurrection, about which there is no doubt, but most of the people do not know.'" (al-Jashiyah/45: 26)
text.67:
Allah has sent messengers to every people until the time of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Each messenger brought a different sharia (Islamic law) than the sharia of other messengers, according to the circumstances, place, and time in which that people lived, so that they could practice it well and according to their ability, benefit, and needs of life.

The Torah was revealed to Moses (peace be upon him), to be conveyed to the Children of Israel. At that time, the Children of Israel were infected with materialism and a materialistic life. Their lives were based on material things. For them, life was all about material objects. When Prophet Moses left the Children of Israel, when he ascended Mount Sinai to receive the Torah, they made a golden calf idol to worship. The content of the Torah provides many instructions to humans on how to build themselves and the community to avoid materialism and a materialistic life. Similarly, the Gospel was revealed to Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him), providing many instructions on how to build the psyche and spirit, in accordance with the condition of the Jews at that time.

Finally, the Qur'an was revealed to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). The sharia contained in the Qur'an is the sharia for all of humanity until the end of time. In the Qur'an, there are many verses that instruct humans to think about spiritual life as well as worldly life, as worldly life is a preparation for the afterlife.

Such is the decree of Allah that applies to all of humanity from the past until now. Therefore, the disbelievers should not oppose the call of Prophet Muhammad that was conveyed to them. Therefore, Allah warns Prophet Muhammad and his ummah (community) not to be influenced by the challenges and disobedience of the disbelievers. Continue to carry out da'wah (invitation to Islam), calling them with wisdom and good advice, inviting them to tawhid (the oneness of God), which leads to happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.68:
If the disbelievers oppose and deny the Prophet's da'wah, even though evidence and explanations have been conveyed to them that demonstrate the truth of the religion conveyed to them, then the Prophet Muhammad's task is to convey the religion, not to make someone a disbeliever or a believer. Everything is within Allah's authority. Allah says:

And if they deny you (Muhammad), then say, "For me is my deed, and for you is your deed. You are disassociated from what I do, and I am disassociated from what you do." (Yunus/10: 41)

Tell them that Allah knows best about what they do and will recompense them for the deeds they have done in this world.
text.69:
After Allah commanded in the previous verses that the Messenger of Allah turn away from the disbelievers, in this verse Allah affirms that Allah will determine the decision and judgment on the Day of Resurrection between those who dispute in matters of religion, so that it is proven which is right and which is wrong.

Those who believe are patient and strengthen their faith, as Allah says:

Therefore call (them to faith) and remain steadfast (in faith and preaching) as you are commanded (Muhammad), and do not follow their desires and say, "I believe in the Book that Allah has sent down, and I am commanded to be just among you." (ash-Shura/42: 15)
text.70:
This verse affirms to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, the vastness of Allah's knowledge. Although the Prophet Muhammad is addressed, this verse includes all of his ummah. It is as if Allah is saying to him, "Do you not know, O Muhammad, that Allah's knowledge is immense, encompassing everything in the heavens and everything on earth? Nothing escapes His knowledge, even if it is the size of a *zarroh* (atom) or smaller than an atom. Indeed, He knows everything that stirs in the hearts of people."

All of Allah's knowledge is written in *Lauh Mahfuz*, which is a book in which everything that exists is mentioned, and that book has existed and is complete, containing records from before Allah created the heavens and the earth. According to Abu Muslim al-Ashfahani, what is meant by "book" in this verse is the preservation of something and its perfect recording. There is nothing that is not recorded in it. This is the knowledge of Allah.

Perfect knowledge and complete recording of everything, as well as the establishment of laws that will be used as the basis for judgment in the Hereafter, are not difficult for Allah to establish. He will establish everything in the Hereafter with the utmost justice, because all the things that are used as considerations are already recorded by Him, lacking nothing at all.
text.71:
Allah explains that the beliefs of the polytheists are wrong, whether viewed from the perspective of revelation, reason, or the attitude of the polytheists themselves when they hear the verses of Allah.

1. The polytheists of Mecca worship other than Allah, by worshipping idols that they make themselves. Their belief is not based on revelation that Allah sent down to His Messenger, whereas a true belief is one that is based on revelation from Allah. Their belief is only based on the customs of their ancestors, which they then follow and believe in.

2. They worship other than Allah, which is not based on correct thinking, and not based on knowledge. They make the idols they worship themselves. Therefore, they will not find a helper who will help them to uphold their opinions and thoughts, or who will ward off punishment from them in the Hereafter.

3. When the verses of Allah are recited to them, signs of arrogance, pride, and hardness of heart appear on their faces, as well as angry words that arise in their hearts. When the verses of the Qur'an are recited to them, they want to attack and beat the people who are reciting the verses. If they wanted to seek the truth, they would listen to the verses that are recited, then they would contemplate and think about them, and if there was something that displeased them, they would ask or seek strong reasons to refute the truth of the verses of Allah.

Then Allah threatens them that their hatred and anger at hearing the verses of Allah is actually less than the pain of the punishment that they will feel later on the Day of Judgment.

Allah affirms His threat to the polytheists by commanding the Prophet Muhammad saw to say to them, "O polytheists, do you want to hear news that is greater and more evil than your anger towards those who read the verses of Allah, so that you almost attack and beat them?"

Then the above question is answered directly, that the great news and worse than their anger is the punishment of Hell that has been promised to the disbelievers as a reward for their actions while living in the world. Hell is the worst place of return prepared for the polytheists.
text.72:
Allah explains that the beliefs of the polytheists are wrong, whether viewed from the perspective of revelation, reason, or from the attitude of the polytheists themselves when they hear the verses of Allah.

1. The polytheists of Mecca worship other than Allah, by worshipping idols that they make themselves. Their belief is not based on revelation that Allah sent down to His Messenger, whereas a true belief is one that is based on revelation from Allah. Their belief is only based on the customs and traditions of their ancestors, which they then follow and believe in.

2. They worship other than Allah, which is not based on correct thinking, and not based on knowledge. They make the idols they worship themselves. Therefore, they will not find a helper who will help them to uphold their opinions and thoughts, or who will ward off punishment from them in the Hereafter.

3. When the verses of Allah are recited to them, signs of arrogance, pride, and hardness of heart appear on their faces, as well as angry words that arise in their hearts. When the verses of the Qur'an are recited to them, they want to attack and beat the people who are reciting the verses. If they wanted to seek the truth, they would listen to the verses that are recited, then they would reflect and think about them, and if there was something that displeased them, they would ask or seek strong reasons to refute the truth of the verses of Allah.

Then Allah threatens them that their hatred and anger at hearing the verses of Allah is actually smaller than the pain of the punishment that they will feel later on the Day of Judgment.

Allah affirms His threat to the polytheists by commanding the Prophet Muhammad saw to say to them, "O polytheists, do you want to hear news that is greater and more evil than the anger in your hearts towards those who recite the verses of Allah, so that you almost attack and beat them?"

Then the question above is answered directly, that the great news and worse than their anger is the punishment of Hell that has been promised to the disbelievers as a reward for their deeds while living in the world. Hell is the worst place of return prepared for the polytheists.
text.73:
This verse calls upon mankind, especially those who associate partners with Allah by worshipping idols made from inanimate objects and created by themselves, to pay attention to the parable that Allah has made for them, then to reflect and contemplate it in the best possible way. They should consider whether what they have done is in accordance with sound reasoning, and they should reflect again on the verses of Allah that are recited, so that they may receive guidance.

The parable is that all the idols they worship, with the aim of drawing closer to Allah, and to whom they make requests, cannot create anything. Likewise, if an idol possessed something, and that thing was snatched away by a small, weak, and powerless fly, then the idols they worship would certainly not be able to retrieve that thing back from the small fly.

The parable presented by Allah in this verse seems to warn those who worship idols or inanimate objects that the Lord who deserves to be worshipped is the All-Powerful, the Creator, and there is no power that can overcome His power. If the disbelievers worship idols, it means they are worshipping inanimate objects, which know nothing, and cannot even defend what they possess, even if a small, powerless fly were to snatch it away from them. Is such an idol worthy of worship? The actions of the polytheists demonstrate their ignorance. How mistaken are those who worship the idol, and so too is the idol that is worshipped.
text.74:
The polytheists claimed that they worshipped idols or statues in order to draw closer to Allah. But their claim was refuted by Allah, stating that the way they did it not only insulted Allah, but also implied that Allah could not directly accept requests and grant the prayers of His servants, so there needed to be something to help Him as an intermediary.

Indeed, Allah, who is rightfully worshipped, is the Most Powerful and Mighty, the All-Dominant, and nothing can defeat Him. He does what He wills, unlike the idols worshipped by the polytheists, which cannot even reclaim something that a fly has snatched from them. Allah says:

"Indeed, Allah is the [sole] Provider, the Possessor of strength, the Firm." (adz-dzariyat/51: 58)
text.75:
It is narrated that Walid bin Mugirah once said, "Has the revelation been sent down upon him among us?" Then Allah revealed this verse.

In this verse, Allah explains that He has chosen some among the angels to be intermediaries between Him and the Messengers He sent, to deliver revelation, such as the angel Jibril. Likewise, Allah has chosen some Messengers who will convey His religion to mankind. The right to choose the Messengers is Allah's right, and no one is authorized to determine it other than Him. Allah is All-Hearing of everything uttered by His servants, seeing their condition and knowing the extent of their abilities, so that He can determine and choose who is worthy to be a Messenger or Prophet among them.

Hadith of the Prophet saw, he said:

"Indeed, Allah has chosen Musa as Kalimullah and Ibrahim as Khalilullah." (Narrated by al-Hakim in al-Mustadrak from Ibn 'Abbas).
text.76: Allah is All-Knowing of the state of the angels and the state of mankind, both before they were created and after they were created, and He also knows their state after they cease to exist. Allah is All-Knowing of what will happen, what has happened, and He also knows the end of all things, because to Him is the return of all matters.
text.77:
In this verse, Allah commands those who believe to:

1. Perform prayer (salat) at the appointed times, complete with its conditions and pillars (rukun). In this verse, prayer is referred to as "ruku'" and "sujud," because ruku' and sujud are characteristic of prayer and are included in its pillars.

2. Submit oneself, repent to Allah, and worship Him. This is a manifestation of faith in the depths of the heart that has felt the greatness, power, and majesty of Allah, because human beings are very dependent on Him. He alone creates, maintains the continuity of life, and regulates all of His creation. Worshiping God can be done directly, such as through prayer (salat), fasting in the month of Ramadan, paying zakat, and performing the Hajj pilgrimage. There is also worship that is not done directly, such as doing good to fellow human beings, helping one another, and cultivating the nature created by Allah for the benefit of mankind.

3. Perform good deeds, such as strengthening ties of kinship (silaturrahmi), having good character, respecting one another, and loving one another. This includes carrying out the commands of Allah.

If people carry out these three types of commands above, then they will succeed in life, obtaining happiness and peace of mind, and in the afterlife they will obtain a paradise full of delights.
text.78:
Besides the commands above, Allah also commands those who believe to strive in the path of Allah with sincerity, solely for Allah's sake, and the Muslims should not feel worried or afraid of anyone in striving except Allah.

There are four types of jihad in the path of Allah:

1. Jihad in the sense of defending oneself from enemy attacks, as Allah says:

And fight in the way of Allah those who fight you but do not transgress. (al-Baqarah/2: 190)

2. Jihad in the sense of upholding Allah's religion and exalting it, as Allah says:

And fight them until there is no fitnah and [until] the religion, all of it, is for Allah. And if they cease, then indeed, Allah is Seeing of what they do. (al-Anfal/8: 39)

3. Jihad in the sense of striving to free oneself from the temptations of Satan, which leads to humanitarian issues such as helping people, working for good, and so on, as Allah says:

Those who believe fight in the cause of Allah, and those who disbelieve fight in the cause of Taghut. So fight against the allies of Satan. Indeed, the plot of Satan has ever been weak. (an-Nisa'/4:76)

4. Jihad in the sense of fighting against one's desires, as explained in the hadith of the Prophet: From Jabir, he said, "A group of people who had just returned from battle came to the Messenger of Allah (saw). He said, "You have come with a good arrival, you have come from the lesser jihad and will enter the greater jihad." Someone said, "What is the greater jihad?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "The struggle of a servant against his desires." (Narrated by al-Khatib al-Baghdadi)

Initially, warfare was disliked by the Muslims, as Allah says:

Fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you. (al-Baqarah/2: 216)

Even though war is disliked by the Muslims, because its purpose is to defend oneself and uphold Allah's religion, warfare is permissible and the Muslims must do it. At the same time, Allah forbids the Muslims from committing acts that transgress in warfare.

In this verse, it is explained that Allah has chosen the Ummah of Muhammad to perform jihad. This command comes because the religion brought by Muhammad is the religion that Allah has perfected, which contains provisions regarding Jihad. This is Allah's help to the Prophet Muhammad and his Ummah.

Allah explains that the religion He has revealed to Muhammad is not a narrow and difficult religion, but a spacious religion that does not cause difficulty to the servant who practices it. All the commands and prohibitions contained in Islam aim to broaden and facilitate human life, so that they may live happily in this world and in the Hereafter. It is only human desires that influence and create in their minds that Allah's commands and prohibitions feel difficult to carry out.

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said that the religion of Islam is easy, and those who burden themselves in religion will be defeated by the religion itself, as mentioned in the hadith:

From Abi Hurairah (ra), from the Prophet (saw), he said, "Indeed, the religion is easy, and no one will ever burden himself in religion except that the religion will defeat him. Therefore, do it correctly, draw near, rejoice, and seek help in the morning and evening and at the time of traveling early at night." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

The Messenger of Allah (saw) once gave a stern warning to a group who burdened themselves in religion, as mentioned in the hadith.

From 'Aisyah (ra), she said, "The Messenger of Allah (saw) once did something, then he made it easy, then that matter reached some of his companions. It was as if they did not like it and left it. Then the matter reached him. He then stood up and gave a speech and said: What is the condition of people who have received news about an act that I have made easy, then they do not like it and leave it? By Allah (said the Messenger of Allah): Indeed, I am the most knowledgeable among them about Allah and the most fearful among them of Him." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

It is narrated that some of the Prophet's companions wanted to compete with him, so one of them said, "I will fast every day." Another said, "I will not marry women." Then that matter reached the Messenger of Allah, and he said:

What is the condition of people who have forbidden women, food, and sleep? Know that I pray and sleep, fast and break my fast, and marry women. Whoever hates my Sunnah, then he is not one of my Ummah. (Narrated by an-Nasa'i)

With the explanation of the hadiths above, it is clear that the religion of Islam is a spacious religion, easing burdens, not narrow-minded and not complicating. If there are practices and deeds of the Islamic religion that are burdensome, narrow-minded, and constricted, then that does not originate from the religion of Islam, but from people who do not know the essence of Islam.

In daily life, it is still evident that many Muslims do not fully understand the purpose of Allah revealing His Sharia to the Prophet (saw). For example, Allah legislates prayer with the aim that humans avoid despicable and evil deeds, but some Muslims feel burdened to perform the five daily prayers, and some of them even say that prayer interferes with their precious time. Likewise, their opinions about other acts of worship.

Then Allah explains that the religion brought by Muhammad is in accordance with the religion of Ibrahim, the ancestor of the Arabs, and both religions are based on monotheism. It is as if Allah is warning the Arabs at that time, "O Arabs, you claim to embrace the religion brought by your ancestor Ibrahim, therefore follow the religion brought by Muhammad, a religion based on monotheism, there is no narrowness or constriction in it. And Allah calls those who embrace the religion of monotheism "Muslims"."

In this verse, it is mentioned that the Messenger of Allah (saw) will be a witness on the Day of Judgment over his Ummah. The meaning is that he testifies that he has conveyed Allah's message to them, calling them to believe in Allah and to remain steadfast in the religion of Allah, and to worship Allah and carry out His commands and avoid His prohibitions. Meanwhile, the Muslims will be witnesses over mankind on the Day of Judgment, meaning that they have done as the Messenger has done to them, namely that they have called people to believe, conveyed Allah's religion, carried out the tasks entrusted to them by Allah and the Messenger in the best possible way. After that, they leave their affairs to Allah, whether their invitation is accepted or rejected.

Some scholars of Tafsir, in interpreting this verse, state that the Muslims are witnesses over mankind, including in their testimony over the previous Ummahs, to whom Messengers were sent. They know this from Allah through the Qur'an, which explains that the previous Messengers conveyed the religion based on monotheism to them.

All of Allah's commands mentioned can be carried out well, so that the Ummah of Muhammad, who are assigned to be witnesses over mankind on the Day of Judgment, can perform that testimony in the best possible way, then Allah commands them:

1. Always perform the five daily prayers, because prayer keeps humans away from despicable and evil deeds and is a strong connection between the God who is worshiped and His servant.

2. Pay Zakat, in order to cleanse the soul and wealth, in order to narrow the gap between the rich and the poor.

3. Hold fast to the rope of Allah by carrying out His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions.
